articles.headline: Takata Airbag Inquiry Widens
articles.snippet: Federal auto safety regulators are now looking at the possibility that side airbags, not just those in front of the driver and front-seat passenger, may be defective.
articles.abstract: Federal auto safety regulators are now looking at the possibility that side airbags, not just those in front of the driver and front-seat passenger, may be defective.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The recall of potentially defective Takata airbags, one of the largest and most complex auto recalls in the nation’s history, may grow even larger.
articles.byline: By Ron Nixon, Danielle Ivory and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Walmart Plays Catch-Up With Amazon
articles.snippet: Walmart’s announcement of increased investment in e-commerce was a tacit acknowledgment that it had fallen far behind Amazon, a leader in the field.
articles.abstract: Walmart’s announcement of increased investment in e-commerce was a tacit acknowledgment that it had fallen far behind Amazon, a leader in the field.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Walmart announced last week that it was significantly increasing its investment in e-commerce, it tacitly acknowledged that it had fallen far behind Amazon in the race for online customers.

articles.headline: U.S. Prosecutor to Drop Insider Trading Cases Against Seven
articles.snippet: Preet Bharara, United States attorney in Manhattan, moved to drop insider trading charges and convictions, including those against Michael Steinberg.
articles.abstract: Preet Bharara, United States attorney in Manhattan, moved to drop insider trading charges and convictions, including those against Michael Steinberg.
articles.lead_paragraph: The impact of a landmark decision that made it harder to prosecute insider trading was amply demonstrated on Thursday as the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan moved to dismiss the charges and convictions of seven people.

articles.headline: Senate Panel Is Chilly to Puerto Rico’s Pleas and Obama’s Aid Plan
articles.snippet: A committee was critical of the island for what it said were confusing and outdated numbers, and unimpressed with an administration plan to get it out of its financial fix.
articles.abstract: A committee was critical of the island for what it said were confusing and outdated numbers, and unimpressed with an administration plan to get it out of its financial fix.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials from debt-plagued Puerto Rico, hoping for some comfort and sympathy — and even practical advice — from senators at a committee hearing in Washington on Thursday, got little of it.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Debating Ways to Shield Syrian Civilians
articles.snippet: The debate comes as the refugee crisis in Europe and Russia’s military intervention in Syria have increased pressure on President Obama to take more forceful action.
articles.abstract: The debate comes as the refugee crisis in Europe and Russia’s military intervention in Syria have increased pressure on President Obama to take more forceful action.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is locked in a sharp new debate over whether to deploy American military forces to establish no-fly zones and safe havens in Syria to protect civilians caught in its grinding civil war.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Palestinian Anger in Jerusalem and West Bank Gets a Violent Soundtrack
articles.snippet: The political songs, which have a strong following among teenagers, are “made as a way to make the Palestinian people get up and resist,” said a Ramallah music shop owner.
articles.abstract: The political songs, which have a strong following among teenagers, are “made as a way to make the Palestinian people get up and resist,” said a Ramallah music shop owner.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The Palestinian teenagers who came one after another into the True Love gift and music shop on a recent afternoon all had the same request: nationalistic songs — the new ones.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Rami Nazzal

articles.headline: ‘Fire Paul Ryan’? Rebel PACs Hit Republicans, and It Pays
articles.snippet: Most of the money raised by conservative petition drives targeting party leadership has gone not to candidates but to consultants, finance records show.
articles.abstract: Most of the money raised by conservative petition drives targeting party leadership has gone not to candidates but to consultants, finance records show.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The petitions that started surfacing online over a year ago were as incendiary as they were urgent, begging recipients to sign up to “Boot Boehner,” “Dump McConnell,” “Drop a Truth-Bomb on Kevin McCarthy” and “Fire Paul Ryan.”
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: China Cuts Interest Rates for Sixth Time Since November
articles.snippet: The central bank’s move came after data showed growth slipped to 6.9 percent in the third quarter and as the country faced persistently weak inflation.
articles.abstract: The central bank’s move came after data showed growth slipped to 6.9 percent in the third quarter and as the country faced persistently weak inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As China confronts a persistent slowdown in growth, its government moved to pump more money into the economy using stimulus measures that could create other challenges for the country.
articles.byline: By Neil Gough and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Hurricane in Mexico Downgraded to Tropical Storm Patricia
articles.snippet: The hurricane, which meteorologists called the strongest recorded in the Western Hemisphere, toppled trees, triggered landslides and tore off roofs as it slammed into the coast.
articles.abstract: The hurricane, which meteorologists called the strongest recorded in the Western Hemisphere, toppled trees, triggered landslides and tore off roofs as it slammed into the coast.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The strongest hurricane ever known to assault the Western Hemisphere slammed into Mexico’s southwest Pacific Coast on Friday, transforming hotels into makeshift shelters, shuttering schools, closing airports and sending inhabitants racing to bus stations to flee inland.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Malkin, Azam Ahmed and Frances Robles

articles.headline: Why It Makes Good Sense to Save for College Now
articles.snippet: Saving for your children’s college tuition won’t hurt their financial aid eligibility as much as many parents seem to think.
articles.abstract: Saving for your children’s college tuition won’t hurt their financial aid eligibility as much as many parents seem to think.
articles.lead_paragraph: You should save money for college expenses if you possibly can. And if you’re worried about how that savings might hurt your child’s financial aid eligibility, then you’re thinking about it wrong.
